@JustinBauer I am just looking for simple ways to test basic data flows. The basic issues come in trying to decide whether to insert or update rows in destination SaaS. If update, it can create several use cases on what fields to update.
One problem I am seeing with #lowcode and #nocode automations is they usually don‚Äôt have tools to fabricate and test different use cases. I get alerts and can make fixes, but no easy way to test.

A3) The one networking aspect often overlooked in cloud migrations is that network connectivity during a phased transition often has different requirements (bw, cost, security) than what's needed during steady state operations. #CIOTechTalk
@BrendenBosch @GlobalNTT Security by contract and SLAs will eventually land more companies in court and in the headlines #ciotechtalk
@benrothke @GlobalNTT @cloudsa The fine print few read and even fewer understand. Better to take ownership of security and work top-down on policies and responsibilities #ciotechtalk
Q3: How can on-premise assets link up to cloud assets securely? #CIOTechTalk @globalntt https://t.co/ENG3u0iJdW
@DigitalSecArch @SANSInstitute The Sum(Enterprise Managed Clouds) + Sum(SaaS on clouds) = Most enterprises are running on all clouds #CIOTechTalk

@ArsalanAKhan @CIOTechTalk @GlobalNTT The brand, customers, employees, suppliers, and partners are the ones impacted by breaches and incidents. Draw the lines where you will, but ownership is defined by the impacts #ciotechtalk

@CraigMilroy @GlobalNTT Need two playbooks:
- Build ZeroTrust from Day 1
- Refactor to ZeroTrust as #SecurityDebt
#ciotechtalk

A2) IMHO, cloud migrations are agile projects: There's learning, planning, exeution, & transformation in every sprint. Teams should be guided by architect/experts, including a data security specialist, on data security requirements, architecture, & implementation #CIOTechTalk

The real issue is that the architect isn't providing day 2 support, so if the policies aren't documented or security architecture isn't transparent or easy, security will become like swiss cheese very easily #CIOTechTalk

There is always lock in. Moving data isn't free. Architecting new solutions, not free. Changing how users access data, not free. The question really is, how easy/fast/cheap is it to unlock the lock-in when/if required.

#ciochat

A3) And that's why there are data warehouses, data lakes, NoSQL stores, graph databases, etc. So many options, so little known about the use cases and biz value until the data is stored, secured, and available for discovery #ciochat

@Tyler_J_J Hah. If I had a $1 every time that was said. IMHO, the issue is people ask for the solution ("I need a DB spun up") instead of the problem ("Where should we store this data that needs to be joined with the CRM" - for example) #ciochat

@mcdavis10 @colttrickle Probably good $s and time wasted auditing cloud configs gone wild to figure out what the business leaders need and then added steps to reengineer, downsize, or manage better #ciochat
A2) Avoid lift and shift migrations. Define the problem, find the value, architect a solution that meets objectives. #ciochat

@Tyler_J_J @InfoWorld One last point - you can get tremendous speed to market and tools to iterate via #lowcode. If warranted you can go #lowcode to code, but much harder to go from a custom app/code to lowcode

Continuing innovations? 

I call that ongoing enhancements. #Agile BAU
 
#ciochat
If org invests <10% in innovation, then that's a problem. Ideally, there should be too many #innovation initiatives vying for a ~20% target #ciochat

A2) Most orgs should put #innovation projects through a vetting and budgeting exercise just like other initiatives. But the biz value can't be ROI when innovation delivers research, capabilities, or analytics (see prev tweet).

BUT ... 

 #CIOchat
@mcdavis10 Ah. The Google approach. It does work well with scale and talent, but most orgs want more controls and invest too little in #innovation to make this successful #ciochat

#Innovation budgets can

* Deliver POCs (but more work to prod-ready)
* Research (especially on markets + customers)
* Analytics (to know what to invest in)

Innovation on its own doesn't deliver biz value, it delivers capabilities

@Michael_J_Hoke Lastly, with citizen development, a business user is more likely to implement what works more efficiently. Example - a dashboard built by SMEs rather than requirements to Dev/Data teams and then iteratively building one. But citizen dev does require a governance model.

@Michael_J_Hoke 3) It changes the conversation w/ stakeholders. Instead of getting "must-have" requirements that often require custom code,, POCs/demos of capabilities in low/no-code help draw out MVPs by asking "will this work?"

@Michael_J_Hoke 2) App modernizations from code (w/ tech debt) to low/no-code (less/no tech debt) drives the reduction. Keep in mind that many legacy apps had a lot of work/code for implementing UX, integrations, performance that can be 'out of the box' for low/no-code platforms

@Michael_J_Hoke A few ways:

1) First, abstractions in low/no-code apps help to build capabilities w/ less expression and more guard rails. It requires avoiding adding custom code to the low/no-code app only doing so where required. So most low/no-code apps have less/no tech debt by design

Managing technical debt:

* Measure it
* Prioritize it in release planning
* Leverage #DevOps CI/CD w Continuous Testing
* Lifecycle patching and upgrades
* Communicate the state of legacy apps to execs
